Award.AbstractNarration: Over the past three years the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter Astronomy (CARMA) was formed from the merger of two telescope arrays supported by the Division of Astronomical Science's University Radio Observatories (URO) Program, these being Caltech?s Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) array of six 10.4-meter-diameter telescopes, and the Berkeley Illinois Maryland Association (BIMA) array of nine 6.1-meter-diameter telescopes. With commissioning at the new site now complete, CARMA will achieve resolutions as high as 0.2 arcseconds at a wavelength of 1mm and, due to its heterogeneous combination of telescope diameters, will provide excellent imaging over a wide range of angular scales. When new receivers are installed in 2009, CARMA's sensitivity in the 1 mm band will be an order of magnitude greater than that of the previous arrays. The new science enabled by CARMA covers a broad range of astronomical topics, including star formation and molecular clouds, studies of external galaxies, and the investigation of solar system objects. CARMA is a pathfinder for the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) and a pipeline for training experts in the field of millimeter interferometry to take full advantage of ALMA's capabilities for US astronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary goal of this award is to conduct cutting-edge astrophysical research using the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-wave Astronomy (CARMA) for a broad range of science: from the formation of stars to the formation of galaxies and creation of structure in the early universe. The award supports the operations and maintenance of the CARMA, the development of new technical capabilities for the array, the astronomical observations conducted with the array and the data analysis and dessemination of the results.

An additional primary goal of this award is training the next generation of radio astronomers and instrumentalists, as well as future scientists working in the technical jobs in industry and national laboratories.

The array consists of a total of 23 antennas (eight 3.5-meter diameter antennas, nine 6.1-meter diameter antennas, and six 10.4-meter antennas) located on Cedar Flat near the Owens Valley Radio Observatory in California. The antennas work together as an interferometer to produce images of the astronomical sky at wavelengths of 10-mm, 3-mm, and 1.3-mm. CARMA is operated and managed by the California Institute of Technology, University of California Berkeley, University of Illinois, University of Chicago, and University of Maryland, with funds from the NSF and the member institutions.

The primary product of CARMA is scientific data and images that enable the study of gas (molecular, atomic and ionized) and dust in a wide range of objects in the Universe, including the Sunyaev-Zel’dovich (SZ) effect for galaxy clusters, and angular structure in the cosmic background radiation. CARMA’s unique capabilities provide data which fuels ground-breaking research addressing a wide range of major astronomical questions.

The data support research by students, postdoctoral scientists and faculty at the member institutions and in the broad astronomical community. A large fraction of CARMA observing time supports student Ph.D. thesis project; another significant fraction supported science projects lead by postdoctoral scientists. Thirty percent of the array time supports science projects led by members of the broad astronomical community through open calls for proposals.

The primary focus of Chicago's participation in CARMA is imaging of the SZ effect toward massive clusters of galaxies to explore the astrophysics of these enormous objects. At 100,000 times the mass of our galaxy, clusters of clusters are the most massive objects the universe has produced. Gradually forming from the gravitational attraction of small overdence regions in the early universe to the present day, their evolution is critically sensitive to cosmology. The studies conducted with CARMA are being used to understand galaxy clusters and to calibrate the SZ effect as a cosmological probe.

The SZ effect is a unique and powerful cosmological tool. It is a small spectral distortion of the cosmic microwave background, the fossil light from the big bang, caused by scattering of the background photons off of the hot ionized gas that fills the deep gravitational wells of massive galaxy clusters. An amazing fact is that the strenght of the observed SZ effect -  which appears as a shadow against the background at microwave frequencies  - is independent of the distance to the cluster. Therefore CARMA is able to characterize the SZ effect of galaxy clusters no matter how distant.

Over the duration of this award, we have successfully upgraded CARMA for precision measurements of the SZ effect and through detailed observations have improved the calibration of the SZ effect for pursuing increasingly precise cosmological constraints.
